Movie Review - The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen Plot It is 1899 and the world is in peril (yet again) from a mask-wearing freak called, Phantom, who kidnapped a bunch of scientists to make automated weapons and machinery. The Queen's liege, M ( urlLink Richard Roxburgh ) gathers a bunch of highly-strung individuals to foil the freak's attempt to destroy Venice (or so they were made to believe). Throw in tons of unnamed German extras and CGI and you are done. Characters And so, the audience is introduced to the group leader, Allan Quartermain ( urlLink Sean Connery ), an old swashbuckling hunter hiding out in Africa. M also recruits the invisible man, Skinner ( urlLink Tony Curran ), who has an attitude very much like the black dude in any white-cop movie. Skinner is also the designated comic relief. Then comes Mina Harker ( urlLink Peta Wilson of " urlLink La Femme Nikita " fame), a vampyress (if there is ever such a word). She is the supposed "ice-queen" of the movie, being the only female in the group and film for that matter. (Female extras don't count) She also hardly ever breaks out in a sweat while wearing those high-necked gowns of hers and that face veil. (Eeurggh. I would be scratching my neck in desperation if I were her.) The fourth member of the league is Mr Dorian Gray ( urlLink Stuart Townsend , vampire in "Queen of the Damned" aka the guy who would have been Aragorn, thank god he wasn't). Mr Gray's talent if you can call it that, is immortality and immorality. Mina and Grey are the show's designated love/lust couple. Captain Nemo ( urlLink Naseeruddin Shah ) adds international flava to the cast. He doesn't say much but drives a big-ass silver ship and has a car that is the movie's batmobile. What movie is complete without a tortured hero? This is where Dr Jekyll ( urlLink Jason Flemyng ) comes in. He is only wimpy until he becomes Hyde. The process of transformation is as freaky as hell. Another swashbuckler completes the group. Tom Sawyer ( urlLink Shane West ) is your typical American teenager with his devil-may-care attitude. He is also the only one who gets to drive the freakmobile, ie, cute guys get the cool car. He also attempts to charm the lady vampire (Cameron Diaz and Justin Timberlake comes to mind) but it all came to naught, thank god. Sean Connery : This 72 year old definitely has screen presence. He can be saying "baa-baa-black-sheep" and it will still sound good. It was a tad disconcerting to see him punch guys half his age without him keeling over from a heart attack. He may have been the greatest James Bond ever but sheesh, age should be catching up on him right? But then again, he is the executive producer, and I guess he could make himself marry a teenage mermaid in the show if he wanted to. I enjoyed him more as Indiana Jones' dad than as Allan Quartermain. Tony Curran : Well, this guy was covered in white most of the time. He could have been computer generated a la Gollum for all I know. And since he was invisible, I could not see his *ahem* other parts. So no gushing for me. Peta Wilson : I loved her in "La Femme". As the vampira, she was good enough. Didn't stretch her acting abilities alot but it was cool watching her feed on humans. She was a little too healthy looking as a vampire though. She ought to be a little more sallow-skinned like Drusilla from Buffy. Heck, they should have gotten Drusilla to do the job. Stuart Townsend : Forever known as the guy who COULD have been Aragorn. Stupid boy. He was bland as Dorian Gray. He should have brought Lestat into his character. Dorian hardly sizzled with Mina and only the obvious dialogue clued the audience into their supposed chemistry. And man, what is with the moustache? Naseeruddin Shah : Err, who?? Nuff said. Jason Flemyng : As Hulk, oh, I mean Hyde, he growled alot. As mentioned, the transformation process was freaky. *shudder* As Jekyll he was a wimp. An ugly wimp to boot. Shane West : Definitely too pretty to be Tom Sawyer. He had about as much facial hair as Peta Wilson in the show. Perhaps Heath Ledger should have auditioned for the role. I think he was just there for demographic purposes, to rein the millions of girls who loved him in " urlLink Once and Again " and " urlLink A Walk to Remember ". Gripes & Comments Watching the movie was like bad sex. Imagine, you are in a bar and you meet a guy called LXG. He looks sleek, is nicely dressed and he is winking at you. You think to yourself, "aww hell, why not? It is only $7.50." So you bring him up to your room and proceed to ravish him. In bed, he does all the right things but somehow, he doesn't excite. And during the climax he fails to live up to expectations. To top it all of, as soon as he is done, he rolls to the side and starts snoring. So you find yourself staring up at the ceiling wondering what the fuck happened. That is exactly what happened. From all the trailers, I definitely thought that LXG would be the X-men of the month. There were too many characters which affected the amount of screen time each character had. As a result, they are a little thin. And while it was commendable that the writers tried to add conflict within the characters (Jekyll and Hyde is an example), these conflicts were never really dealt with. The show also never explained why "bad" guys like a vampire, an amoral immortal and a building-damage expert would want to join the sorority. I have never read the graphic novel, so I cannot say how much better the book was compared to the movie. The storyline was a little muddled as well. And it seemed like a twist was added because in the book "Making Movies for Dummies", it was stated that all good movies should have a twist. It is also stated that in all good-evil movies, the villain should endeavour to destroy the world. Even CGI effects failed to impress, and it had improbable scenes like the Nautilus navigating through the narrow waterways of Venice. WTF??. One other thing, if Mina was a vampire, why didn't she turn to dust when she was walking on top of Nautilus during the day?? The show could have and should have been much darker with the conflict between good and evil made more obvious among the members. There was an attempt to get the characters to interact. Mina and Dorian, ex-lovers. Mina and Jekyll, unrequited crush. Mina and Tom, a Cameron-Justin attraction. Tom and Allan, a father-son relationship (more like grandpa and grandson). Skinner and everyone, the pain in the ass partner. Unfortunately, Captain Nemo was just there to fulfill his duty as the chauffeur. To top it all off, the bloody screen was turned off at least 1 minute before the credits rolled WHILE the sound was still blasting from the speakers. So I didn't know what happened at the very last bit after the witchdoctor raised his hands up. To give credit, the design was impressive. I absolutely loved the libraries, all covered in books. Overall : Bah. I should have watched S.W.A.T instead. At least I know what to expect from such a movie. I would pay only $6.50 for this. I think I will buy the graphic novel.

Bits and Bites So today I went back to school to collect my CONVOCATION GOWN ! Woohoo! Thanks to SARS, we can now keep our convocation gown and mortarboard for a mere $20.80. Trying out the gowns was fun. We pretended that we were Chinese Opera performers because of the long sleeves. We kind of waddled in our gowns because some were too big. I got my transcript as well. Another Woohoo for me! Nothing fantastic on the script only the Merit. I was telling my friend that if I had gotten a First Class Honours, I would parade around with that piece of paper with the "First Class Honours" highlighted in yellow. We were given a free gown bag to dump all our junk in; gown, mortarboard, yellow hood, transcript, invitation cards and other pieces of trash. I also ordered a shiny redwood plaque. Bah. It cost me a whopping $73 but I figured it was more worth it than the graduation bear. The bear was cute, but I have no space in my room for another soft toy. I now have to get myself close-toed shoes and a long-sleeved shirt to wear with the gown because of the strict dress code. Sigh, and I was banking on wearing my blue/yellow sneakers and a halter top for the occasion. Hee. At least shopping for shoes will be fun! Oooh! I had my FAVOURITE ban mian at the foodcourt in Jurong Point. Yum! The only place I can get ban mian without the pork. My tongue is still slightly burnt because I drank the soup while it was still hot. Ahh, I miss going to Jurong Point. Watched LXG just now. Will definitely do a review about it tomorrow morning. I can barely keep my eyes open now and I am having a hiccup as I type this post. PS: For those who don't know, my convocation ceremony will be on the 12th of September at 3.00pm.

Dreams I had a bizarre dream last night. I committed a fashion faux pas by going out in the ugliest, UGLIEST pair of pants ever! It was full of printed flowers and was yellow in colour. It was one of those baggy drawstring pants that billowed around my thighs. To top it all off, I was wearing a printed T-shirt! Like oh my gawd! Prints and prints DO NOT go well together. The colour of the t-shirt clashed with the pants. It was orange, if I'm not mistaken. YUCK ! I must have looked like a moron that even my dream friends commented on it and advised me to get myself a new pair of pants and shoes. So I bought a pair of black capri pants and funky blue Nikes. Hee After that, I must have gone on a holiday or something because I was in a dorm full of girls , sharing just one bathroom. They all seemed unwashed and when I was about to take my shower, one of them hid in the bathroom with me. Don't ask me what was she doing there because I was trying to get over the shock of having a girl share toilet space with me.

The Many Things I Miss Watching soccer Sigh. I can't believe I'm saying this. For those who know me, know that I absolutely detest watching soccer on tv. Somehow, this dislike has lessened over the past few months. I got used to watching all those international friendlies on tv in the mornings. I had no idea who was playing most of the time, and the only players I could recognise were the cute players from Real Madrid and the other English teams. I definitely could recognise Casillas, seeing as how I had a MAJOR crush on him during the world cup days. Why watch soccer when I hate it? Let me qualify that I only like watching the world cup, and even so, only for one half of a game. But when they had those friendlies in the mornings, I actually watched an entire match! It was pretty exciting. I know close to nothing about all those soccer terms. I only know one has to kick the ball into the opposite goal. Maybe I oughta get cable so I can have access to all the leagues going on. Hmm, that might be an overdose for me. Going for lessons Yes. I miss school in general. I miss having the "pleasure" of waking up and rushing for an 8.30 am class. I also miss cutting class and doodling on my lecture notes. I had always made it a point to cut at least 1 tutorial and 1 lecture for every subject every semester. Maybe that's why my grades weren't fantastic. Hee. Whenever we cut class, we would then go to the canteen to eat and chat/gossip/bitch. Rarely do we cut to do our readings, unless it was a major project that was due that very day. Hall life Living in the dorms is one of the best things ever. Independence for at least 5 days a week at only $155 per month and without having to pay for utilities and internet connection at all! I miss walking to the nearest 7-11 at 2.00am with a friend because we were bored and hungry. I miss attempting to run the horrid 179 bus route at nights, which I could eventually do without stopping. I miss blogging at 4.00am after doing tutorials for half the night. I miss crashing over at a friend's room while studying together. I miss going for a swim in the mornings when it is hot and sunny. Playing computer games Playing games need alot of time. At least a few hours at a stretch, a luxury I don't have right now. There was a point in time when I used to skip lectures because I was busy building my empire in Pharoah. Yes, yes, it's an unhealthy thing to do, but I can be cooped up in the room for hours and hours sitting in front of the pc playing the game. Pharoah, Sims, Starcraft, Command & Conquer were all my best friends at some point in my life. I even tried that game Counterstrike for the hell of it but I sucked. I could not run and shoot straight to save my life.

The Many Ways of Saying No Working in a call center is definitely not for the short-tempered, especially when customers have a zillion ways of saying NO. Such a short word, and yet the hardest to say nicely. Three weeks into the job and I've heard many variations of the brusque NO. The customer is typically male, most likely to be working in local firm. He will usually butt in during the introduction and say "No! No! No!" a couple of times before hanging up on you without even saying good bye. If he "allows" you to go on, there usually would be grunting on his end, to show that he is listening to the conversation. After which, he will proceed to say "No. No. No." and then hang up. Sometimes if you're lucky, you will get a seemingly polite man or woman who would listen to your speech and sound interested. But when it comes to the crunch, they will start backpeddling so fast they would be hit by a car if they were on the road. These people have an aversion to saying "No", so they invent a thousand and one excuses to reject your request. It is obvious that they are backpeddling because they try out various excuses until you back off. "I'm not free now" "Actually, I will not be free till the end of the year" "I'm in the middle of a conference" "I will be travelling for the next few months and won't be back till Oct" Following that, you may get secretaries who screen calls for their bosses. And being the little miss bitches that they are, they assume the role of "boss" when they are on the phone. No doubt these women have gotten the green light to screen calls, but they get so snide about it. Without even asking the boss, they will say that he isn't interested. "Oh, I don't think that Mr Lee will be interested. No need to call back. Oh, no need to ask for the address either because he isn't interested" It is extremely annoying when the receptionist asks for your name, company and intention for calling as though she would put the call through, only to inform you that the person you're looking for has died/resigned/relocated/retired. Three weeks into the job and I'm dying. A little part of me dies everytime I make a call. I need to get out. HELP
The Many Faces of Ewan McGregor (drool) Dumbass Quiz: From which movies did the photos come from? Note: Only the B&W photo did not come from a movie. I took it because he looked good in it. *grin*

Ways to Annoy People 1. Sing the Batman theme incessantly. 2. Learn Morse code, and have conversations with friends in public consisting entirely of "Beeeep Bip Bip Beeeep Bip..." 3. Speak only in a "robot" voice. 4. Sniff incessantly. 5. Reply to everything someone says with "that's what YOU think." 6. Invent nonsense computer jargon in conversations, and see if people play along to avoid the appearance of ignorance. 7. Finish all your sentences with the words "in accordance with prophesy." 8. Do not add any inflection to the end of your sentences, producing awkward silences with the impression that you'll be saying more at any moment. 9. Holler random numbers while someone is counting. 10. Signal that a conversation is over by clamping your hands over your ears. 11. Change channels five minutes before the end of every show. 12. Begin all your sentences with "ooh la la!" 13. ONLY TYPE IN UPPERCASE. 14. Wander around a restaurant, asking other diners for their parsley 15. Inform others that they exist only in your imagination. [Writer's note: If any of you do that to me, I swear, I'll throw my shoe at you. Other than that, enjoy!]

Morning Madness Are you awake early enough to even have a morning routine? If so, what do you do? I love morning routines, not because it is organised and boring but because I can accomplish a certain number of things before my brain actually starts functioning. You see, I wake up at a freakish hour of 7 to 7.30 every day, including weekends as well. There is no point telling me to sleep in because it doesn't work. The latest I can sleep until is 8.30 am or 9. However, I'm not one of those perky morning people, despite my early wake up times. And so, I have a routine that I follow fairly religiously every day so that my brain will get used to being awake. The first thing I do when I wake up is read the newspapers. As biased as the urlLink Straits Times can be, it is the only source of information I have at my doorstep. While reading the papers, I also tune in to urlLink Channel NewsAsia for the business and other prime time news, hence, my "crush" on the dishy urlLink Tim Go (without the H as fluke pointed out). My other business hunk, Jack Sung, left the tv station, and was replaced by a girl . Reading the papers would take anywhere from 30 mins to even an hour, depending on how thorough I want to be. I refuse to go out without reading the papers first and so I'd rather be late than skip my daily readings. Only after reading the papers and checking my emails online will I then be remotely ready to leave the house. On days I have tuition, I would leave by 9. Other days would be spent bumming around or exercising. I love bumming around and doing nothing. My weekends would be similar. My Saturdays start even earlier because I have tuition at a godawful time of 8.30am. The routine goes down the drain whenever I have a new game to play. Recently it was urlLink the Sims . (Hot Date & Livin' Large). I spent up to 8 to 10 hours a day playing that darned game, stopping only for food and a shower. I did the same thing when I was hooked on urlLink Pharoah . I absolutely love that game.

Exactly! Which is why its so ironic that one of Bush's reasons for going to war with Iraq was to quell the threat of terrorism. Well, that obviously went really well. Oh but wait, do we even know what the reason for going to war was anymore? The agenda keeps changing, its hard to keep up. First it was to remove WMD, then its to quell terrorism, and when they actually got there and started shooting at people, its to liberate the Iraqis! Wow! All these altruistic notions spewing forth from the USA. Who would have thought?

Violence begets violence I am not wont to write about serious issues on this site, hmm, unless one considers lifestyle problems a serious issue. But frankly I am sick of waking up in the mornings only to read and watch about the spate of bombings occurring in the world today. Even the dishy newsreader, Timothy W Goh (hee) isn't dishy enough to distract me from the news. Bombings in urlLink Mumbai and the urlLink Middle East have made this week a particularly gruesome one. Bomb blasts in Bali and Jakarta have brought the problem closer to home and no country can pretend to be free from the terrorist threat. It's ironic isn't it that violence is used to achieve peace? But as one can see, it DOESN'T work. If it does, the world should be at peace now and Iraq should be on its way to recovery. But as we all know, that isn't going to happen anytime soon. The cycle of violence perpetuates when the warring sides refuse to rise above it. Tit for tat, an eye for an eye, and blood for blood. Everyone vows revenge. Martyrdom has never been so popular before. The promise of heaven is a good enough lure for suicide bombers to strap on the bomb vest and blow him/herself up. It is also easier to blame other people for one's own problems. Everyone is the enemy, and currently, enemy #1 is the Western world. The roots of violence run deep and encompass a myriad of factors, economic and social problems among other things. The impacts of bombings have far-reaching consequences than just immediate revenge and death. But if no one is willing to stop and break the cycle of violence, then we will all sing: This is the war that doesn't end Yes it goes on and on my friend Some people started killing men not knowing what's the loss And they'll continue killing men forever just because... [repeat again until infinity] - Adapted from "Lamb Chops Playalong"

MOVIE REVIEW - DOWN WITH LOVE Ladies and gentlemen, let me get this off my chest right now, "EWAN MCGREGOR IS HOT !!!!" There, I've said it. Now I can begin my review. Plot A gem of a movie starring Ewan McGregor, Renee Zellweger, David Hyde Pierce and Sarah Paulson. Set in the 60s in New York City, Down With Love casts Renee as Barbara Novak, a writer who opines that women can have sex a la carte just like men and Ewan as Catcher Block, a writer for a man's magazine and also known as a ladies' man, a man's man and man about town. Sarah and David are Barbara's and Catcher's respective bosses. The movie shows the budding romance between the two leads while they are pretending to be people they are not. At the same time, Catcher's boss, Peter (Hyde Pierce) is attempting to have his own romance with Renee's editor, Vicky (Paulson). After being publicly snubbed by Barbara because he failed to turn up for any of his interviews with her (he was supposed to do a cover story on Barbara for the magazine), he vows to get the expose on Barbara. His "beautifully" crafted plan to get her to fall in love with the persona he created, Zip Martin, a Texan astronaut, unravels like a torn rug when the tables were turned on him. He fell in love with her instead. Characters urlLink Renee was adorable as the feminist advice writer, Barbara. With her endless supply of fabulous clothes, she looked great in every scene she was in. Her perky attitude was just right and not too saccharine for my taste. She pulled her role off with aplomb, great clothes aside. urlLink Ewan was HOT! As Catcher Block, he had the right combination of playboy charm and new-age sensitivity. He was also able to maintain a credible Texan accent throughout the show. He proves again that he is a versatile actor, and comedy can be added to his list growing of talents. To think that this is the same guy who acted in urlLink Trainspotting as a heroin addict. Personally, I thought urlLink David Hyde Pierce stole the show. Comedy is certainly his forte. With his deadpan face, he spouted his one-liners perfectly. He was able to get the audience rolling around laughing with just a look, without having to resort to slap-stick comedy (unlike some comedians I know). His neurotic character certainly brought to mind his other character, Niles from Fraisier. urlLink Sarah Paulson was also suited for her role. As Barbara's editor, she shared runway space with her. Comments In one word, the movie was CUTE. It was light and frothy like a pina colada on a hot day. Another plus point was the fantastic dialogue. The witty repartee between Ewan and Renee as well as with David was fabulous. Double entendres abound and it culminated in a split-screen visual that was absolutely hilarious. One thing I liked about the show was that it didn't pretend to be a serious, thought-provoking movie. With the retro backdrop - bright colours, an almost comic-like Manhattan scenery, and tons of retro-chic clothes, the movie was anything BUT heavy. Issues on feminism and male-chauvinism were dealt with so lightly that it was like powdered sugar on a cinnamon roll. Overall I enjoyed myself thoroughly. Worth paying $8.50 for it. Of course the biggest draw was Ewan and David. Ewas was HOT!!

Movie Plans So many movies and so little time and money. I would eventually want to watch: 1) urlLink Down With Love 2) urlLink The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen 3) urlLink Pirates of the Caribbean 4) urlLink Freaky Friday 5) urlLink The Unborn (Thai) Will I be desperate enough to watch them alone??? hee, only time will tell.

Men Psychology 101 A man is dating three women and wants to decide which to marry. He decides to give them a test. He gives each woman a present of $5,000 and watches to see what they do with the money. The first does a total makeover. She goes to a fancy beauty salon, gets her hair done, purchases new make-up and buys several new outfits, and dresses up very nicely for the man. She tells him that she has done this to be more attractive for him because she loves him so much. The man is impressed. The second goes shopping to buy the man gifts. She gets him a new set of STRONG golf clubs, some new gizmos for his computer, and some expensive clothes. As she presents these gifts, she tells him that she has spent all the money on him because she loves him so much. Again, the man is impressed. The third invests the money in the stock market. She earns several times the $5,000. She gives him back his $5000 and reinvests the remainder in a joint account. She tells him that she wants to save for their future because she loves him so much. Obviously, the man was impressed. The man thought for a long time about what each woman had done with the money. Then he married the one with the largest breasts . Writer's note: This was from an email attachment, thanks to Liyun for forwarding it to me.

Bent by the Toy Factory Theatre Ensemble and directed by Beatrice Chia. Another gay play for me. A little synopsis: Berlin 1934: Suave, debonair playboy, Max, is living the decadent and promiscuous Berlin nightclub life. Though dedicated to his lover Rudy, who performs in the cabaret, Max's one-night stand with an attractive German soldier leaves them running for their lives as Hitler's Gestapo closes in on them. Toy Factory is proud to present Martin Sherman's award-winning and groundbreaking BENT - the first play to bring Nazi persecution of homosexuals into the spotlight. R(A)18.

LET'S BOOGIE Bar top dancing is all the rage these days in Singapore. When bar top dancing and the impacts of its legalisation is a topic for Prime Time Morning TV, you know that it is the next "in" thing. Men love watching the women, women love being on the bar tops and pub owners are relishing in the "ka-ching" of the cash registers. Unfortunately, not all bar top dancers are like the Coyotes in Coyote Ugly. Ooh mamma, those honeys are HOT! Some dance just by wriggling their butts from side to side, everything else remains stationary. Then there is the popular left feet-right feet shuffle, no butt wriggling involved. Have you ever seen the no butt wiggle but knees bounce up and down dance? Rather than go sideways, the dancer is actually just bouncing on the spot. Some girls are more adventurous. They wiggle their butts and torsos so vigorously that they look as though they might pull a muscle. Alot of dancing also involves audience interaction. The women would wiggle and point at various people in the crowds. Let's not neglect the men here. Of all the bar top men I've seen, only one could dance, although I think he was more woman than man, if you get my drift. Men have their own way of dancing as well. The feet shuffle is also popular. Since men can't isolate their hips, any hip/butt movement is accompanied with a knee or upper body sway. Whatever the dance style, it sure takes guts, alcohol induced or otherwise, to get on top a bar counter and parade yourself for the world (ok, the bar patrons) to see/admire/bitch.

urlLink MEDICAL TERMS PT 2 1) Assmosis : Promotion by kissing ass 2) Brown trout : A stool that doesn't float, as opposed to an air biscuit, which does 3) Code brown : Incontinence-related emergency 4) Departure lounge : Geriatric ward 5) Freud squad : Psychiatrists 6) Digging for worms : Varicose vein surgery 7) Ohno-second :The moment when you realise something has gone horribly wrong 8) Ostrich treatment : Pretend it's not there and hope it goes away 9) Smellybridge : The skin between the anus and the posterior aspect of the scrotum 10) Whopper with cheese : Fat woman with thrush

MEDICAL TERMS PT 1 urlLink Acronyms and phrases you would not want to see on your medical report: 1) CTD - Circling the Drain : about to die 2) TTFO - Told to Fuck Off 3) LOBNH - Lights On But Nobody Home 4) CNS-QNS - Central Nervous System - Quantity Not Sufficient 5) Pumpkin Positive - So lacking in brain matter that when a penlight is shone in the mouth, the head would light up 6) DBI - Dirt-Bag Index: the number of tattoos a patient has X the number of missing teeth = the number of days since patient last bathed. 7) FTF - Failure to fly, for attempted suicide victims 8) PFO - Pissed, fell over. A common A&E diagnosis 9) SIG - Stroppy, ignorant git 10) TFBUNDY - Totally fucked but unfortunately not dead yet. Best avoided in the medical notes 11) FUBAR - Fucked up beyond all recognition

EXTREME MAKEOVER Before After Well, Mediacorp has once again filled our tv slot with more BAD tv shows and adding to the ever-growing list is Extreme Makeover . Every week, 3 "lucky" people will get to have their greatest wishes fulfilled. Tummy tucks, lasik surgery, lipo, teeth straightening, extra eyebrows, a third head, whatever you want, the "extreme team" will make it possible. I don't even want to dignify the show with a review, which is why I'm just going to bitch about it. I hate to sound moralistic and take on a "holier-than-thou" attitude, but really, it is in my opinion that one should be thankful for what you are born with. Yes, so no one can have perfect Cup C breasts, or huge almond-shaped eyes, but at least you have two eyes and breasts right? To be fair to the participants, they do look as though they need help. But then again, it is quite sad to know that these people place such a hugh emphasis on their lack of looks such that they need to alter their appearances to make themselves feel better. But as I've said before, who am I to judge right? If I could take part in such a show, I would shop for bigger boobs. Hee.

We've Got the Transport Blues So the decision to let Buangkok station remain closed and the closure of certain bus routes still stands. I mean, what do we expect? As if urlLink SBS will retract their decision, or that urlLink the Government will not stand by their side . After all, the bus operator has to remain profitable in order to provide better service right? We can't let them go in the red, or subsidise their operating costs. SBS is a listed company and is answerable to its shareholders. Public amenities be damned. Bottom-line is the company has to be profitable, so that means, increasing fares (NEL is more expensive) and decreasing costs by closing train stations due to low human traffic and re-routing certain bus routes to prevent duplication with the NEL. Is your life made more difficult? Too darned bad for you. You should be thankful that urlLink feeder services will be provided to get you to the nearest MRT station. Anyway, according to the Transport Minister, taking a bus-train-bus route is more predictable than a direct bus route. In the long run, the increase in transport costs for the average commuter should be mitigated by the fact that travelling is made more predictable. The minister also warned that "if the operator keeps bus services which duplicate train routes, it'll mean higher fares for commuters." I guess he overlooked the fact that the very same bus routes duplicate the rival (SMRT) train routes. If you think that you're an important factor in any transport decision merely because you are the commuter, think again. The minister also ruled out the idea of "consulting residents before making the cuts, as bus routes cannot be tailored to individual needs but have to serve the greatest number of people." As SBS's urlLink profit decreased in the second quarter , we should all do our part to ensure that it remains profitable, especially if we want better service. Better service in terms of slow bus driving tactics that drivers use when they are ahead of their schedule and long waiting times during peak hours.

Body Beautiful The quest for that perfect body continues. We are obsessed with our bodies. Fat asses, big thighs and jiggly tummies are causes of concern for women striving for that perfect body. As a result, we resort to pills, diets, exercise and a multitude of "acceptable" weight-loss programs to make us feel "less fat". Is this for health or vanity? How much of why we want to lose weight is because we are grossly unhealthy or because we just want to look good in a string bikini? When we exercise to lose weight, is maintaining a healthy lifestyle a secondary reason as opposed to the goal of achieving a toned body? Then again, does it actually matter? Sometimes, the two reasons are so intertwined that we cannot differentiate them anymore. An example: I only go swimming when it's hot and sunny. No doubt, the main reason why I swim is to exercise. But I also like the tan that I get. That's purely for my vanity. So, although I can choose to swim in the evenings, I'd rather not swim at all if I can't swim on a hot and sunny day. However, I don't like to sun-tan, because I would rather exercise and achieve the tan as an added bonus. Health and vanity aside, who are we losing weight for? Ourselves? Family? Boyfriend? Or for the pleasure of hearing compliments about our bodies? Of course, no one is going to admit that. Ever told yourself you want to lose weight so that you can fit into that pair of hipster jeans that is so "in" right now? I have. (But gosh, hipsters don't look good on me) What about that string bikini? Ever want to lose weight to be on the receiving end of an appreciative glance or a wolf whistle? We are our harshest critic. So many of our hang ups can be derived from our perceived weight problem. Of course, I'm not here to judge, as god knows, I've been moaning about my weight "problem" for as long as I can remember. The reasons for losing weight can be varied and frankly, it doesn't matter. Perhaps the most important reason is so that we can feel good about ourselves. If losing weight makes you feel happy, then I say go for it. However, the steps to shed those pounds should be through acceptable means. Starvation, inducing vomit and dangerous diets are harmful to the body and more importantly, it is just plain STUPID . So good luck for your quest. As for me, my exercise program should be sufficient enough for me to achieve my perfect body. (I hope)

MARDI GRAS - by The Necessary Stage A group of people come together to organise Singapores first Pride Parade  Singapores first Mardi Gras. They plan to hold the March in town, with costumes and colours; they want to shout out loud and be proud As they plan, the tension mounts; the cracks in their relationships surface. Jokes turn to bitchiness, which turn to clawing Eventually, the very event that is supposed to show their unity threatens to tear them apart. Are they going to prove themselves to be ONE PEOPLE  of gay men, lesbians and friends; or will the rainbow represent a segregation of colours? Is pink over? This is a play not to be missed, starring Paerin Choa, Natalie Hennedige, Garrett Hoo, Hossan Leong, Jimmy T, Rick Tan and Corrine Adrienne and guest appearances by Kumar and Irene Ang. It was written by Haresh Sharma and directed by Alvin Tan. Plot Underneath the main storyline, several issues were addressed, adding depth to the potentially shallow play. Betrayals (between friends and lovers), love, friendship and kinship bound the play together. Being gay is more than just clubbing, fucking, licking, dancing and partying. Characters Hossan Leong as "Faith" easily had the best lines. He is one bitchy, dramatic sister, so don't go messin' with him. He stole the show, with his dialogue, his expression, his walk and even his dressing. (Gurmit Singh, eat your heart out!). Garrett Hoo plays "Ben", a 30-something straight man with a boyfriend. Being a teacher, he keeps his sexuality in the closet. He is one YUMMY dude. His body is TO DIE FOR. *swoon* Ben is best friends with Faith and Clement played by Rick Tan. He reminded me of Oswald from the Amazing Race. Like Hossan, his portrayal of the effiminate man was flawless. No stereotypical limp-wrist, but tons of "you go girl" hand gestures. Natalie plays Su, the fag hag. She was hilarious and surprisingly, her screechy voice didn't irritate me. Corinne was the token dyke, Sulin. Straight-laced, she was quite a bore to me. Paerin Choo was Brian, Ben's straight brother. Ben's boyfriend, Alex (Jimmy T) is the other hot dude. Kumar guest-starred as Hope, Faith's partner. Sadly, his one scene was pretty flat. Irene Ang plays Glen, Sulin's boyfriend. Comments I enjoyed myself immensely. The dialogue was sharp and witty, with perfect comic timing and excellent one-liners. Although a good part of the play was hilarious, some parts were awfully sad. One particular scene was the breakup between Ben and Alex. That was absolutely heart-wrenching, I almost teared. Definitely, the dialogue was the main draw, peppered with local references which made it even wittier and funnier. The characters suited their roles and although I have minor gripes about certain characters, overall, the show still won me over. It was also interesting to see gays at the theatre. I've not come across many gays in my lifetime and it's just nice to see a number of them all at one place at the same time. Overall Catch the play before it ends! To satisfy your cravings, check out these sites. urlLink Fridae.com - Asia's Gay+Lesbian Network urlLink Hossan's commentary

Looking Back My nickname was sharky. I didn't pick it myself. My group of close friends then - 5 guys and 3 girls, gave it to me. Thinking about it now, I wonder why. Am I fierce? Perhaps. Do I eat people? No; maybe men a la Samantha Jones. Do I look like a shark then?!?!? We had weird nicknames then. Lizard, Protractor, Jing Bear Bear....I squirm at each one as I type them out now. My name tends to bring to mind a whole lot of other quite pugnacious nicknames too. Ez - Ass, Esther - Esso, Esther - Ester (chemical compound), I've given up on the explaining. JC days were great. The first smatterings of interaction with the opposite sex. I was from the convent school for 10 years and although there was absolutely no way I was anything 'nun-nish' about me when I entered JC, it was still an enriching experience. It seemed to me that the people in there could be easily categorized into 3 groups: Study, Play, Find a boyfriend/girlfriend. The Study group - well, you could sight them miles away. In the library, hogging huge door-stop-like books around, always reading lecture notes before and after lectures and tutorials were always properly done and stapled. The Play group - yeah, you knew them too. Skipped lessons, always at Orchard or some bowling alley, went home late, did tutorial skimpily. As for the 3rd group - an enigma. They could also be members of group one and two, depending on their modus operandi to attract the other. Crushes were as rampant as the breakups that ensue. Hearts were mended just as hearts were broken. Fantasies created as fantasies were shattered. I had more than my far share of all. I didn't have crushes on the average guys - the jocks or the dragon boat/basketball/school council guys. They couldn't make it back then; they still couldn't make it in the university. I often wonder by what curse of luck brings me to educational institutions where the guys cohort is skewed by males who simply cannot make the cut. I don't consider myself having unattainable standards. Really. Is asking for proper hygiene, a care of one's appearance, plans for the future, some intellectual tendencies too much??? I figure that such actions do come naturally as one begins caring for another. Won't the desire to look good and appear smart and witty be en route to impressing the potential mate?

Blabbers Watching High School Reunion (HSR) further emphasises that school life plays a big part in shaping a person's character. Since Singapore does not have the high school system, the closest comparison would be with the Junior Colleges (JC) or the polytechinics. My JC life was certainly a memorable experience for me and shaped some of my thinking, especially about friends. Unlike HSR, there weren't stupid labels like "the Jock", "the Player", "the Popular Girl" and so on, at least not that I knew of. Rarely did one person stick out prominently. Groups or cliques featured heavily in school. We had the "in" crowd, who of course, were cool but rowdy. We also had a swimmers crowd, and they occupied a particular place in the canteen known as the "swimmers' table". Other groups included the band people, the Malay society people, rock-climbers, counsellors, exco (executive committee) members and other smaller cliques. The arts faculty students (those who studied Lit, Geog, Hist) tend to stay together because we were the minority. A similarity might be seen in the amount of bitching that is done about people from different groups. My class particularly, wasn't known for our friendliness, and we had the awful habit of giving science students nicknames. Of course, then, the nicknames used to crack us up so much that we spent a lot of time making fun of other people. Among the nicknames created were "daddy long legs", "duck mouth" and "pornstar". Til this day, I still have no idea what their real names are, and all 3 of them studied at NTU with me. My favourite nickname has to be the one I called a girl I really didn't like, because her behaviour was annoying. I called her "Chucky". Hee, yes, in memory of the doll. Nowadays, my friends and I give nicknames to some uni mates but they are less venemous, however still retain a little humour. Crushes, as seen from HSR and various books I've read, have a big impact on the lives of many girls. All those time spent mooning over a guy who was oblivious to the silent attention given to him by the girl. I remember my JC crush very well. I liked him for one and a half years. Never did speak to him although we had Geography classes together. I called him "His Royal Cuteness" or HRC for short. Perhaps, the biggest part of a students' life, aside from the academic aspect of it, has got to be the friends. Somehow at that age, doing things in group were very common. Lunches were taken together, friends sat side by side in class, copied each other's homework, went out together, pee-ed together, bitched together. You get my drift? I found that to be the most exhausting part of being in a group of friends. In such cliques, there has got to be the leader, or alpha-member. As fun as such groups were, keeping up appearances and always worrying about getting on the wrong end of the alpha-members temper was time-consuming. I had to learn that the hard way and it made school life painful for a short while. However, lasting friendships can be forged in the 2 years and I've got close friends from my JC days. Looking back, I've realised nothing much has changed. I still have crushes, my friends still form a great part of my life and I still bitch about certain so-and-sos with fellow NTU friends. However, there is a lesser need to do things in groups and I value my personal time very much. It was a nice trip down memory lane. And lucky for me, I've got tons of photos to look at, if I want to take another trip down that lane.

High School Reunion Oh yay. Mediacorp seems to think that Singaporeans can't get enough of Reality TV that they have to fill every available timeslot with shows from this genre. Adding to the list is the relatively new "High School Reunion" created by the same guy who made "The Bachelor" . Sigh. There is bad tv and there is bad tv. Good trash to watch includes The Amazing Race, Survivor and American Idol. Other reality shits like "Temptation Island", "Blind Date" and "Star Search" falls under category of bad trash. Of course, this is all very biased, so don't bother saying that I'm not being objective because, DUH, I'm not. I was expecting this to be the cousin of "Temptation Island" , or in short, just another fuck fest for horny Americans. The show gathers 17 former classmates on an island in Hawaii for 14 days and basically, the producers must have said, "Go forth and fuck/fight/frolick" because that is what they did. No, they did not fuck/fight/frolick, but the subject of relationships "I've had a crush on him since high school" , fueds "He made my life miserable" and general ramblings is brought up, and from the recaps that I've read, some amount of kiss-kiss does occur later on in the season. The characters are as imaginative as the characters from " urlLink Sweet Valley High ". Hee, remember that series girls? Ooh, you have the jock, the player, the homecoming queen, the nerd, the misfit, the bully, the clown, the bitch, the chubby cheerleader... all chosen for maximum visual impact and conflict. Each of them want something out of this reunion, either a fuck, respect, a marriage or a good time. It was entertaining to watch the show, in a ridiculous sort of way. Ms Tall Girl has had a huge crush on Mr Player since high school and her main purpose is to be married to him at the end of the show. I found that to be really pathetic. I wouldn't want to marry my JC crush ever. Sheesh. Especially if he is a player. So anyway, Mr Player behaves just like the player that he is. Kissed her on their first date, but at the same time saying that he wants to do that with other girls so as to explore his options. Of course he doesn't say it like that, i'm just condensing it. I liked the nerd. But then again, I tend to favour most nerds because I sympathise with them. High school can be such a torture when you're shy and intelligent. [Come to Singapore. The schools here wld love you] Not only that, rumour has it that the nerd is a millionaire. Sigh. My kind of guy. Ms Popular annoys me, so does Ms Flirt and Ms Gossip. Hmm.. I think all of them annoy me except for Mr Misfit and Mr Loner and Mr Nerd. All in all, ok to watch just for the entertainment value. Heh, if anything, I'm sure one can look forward to potential squabbles and romances.

Sigh. I was so ready to do a review about the new tv show " urlLink Brothers 4 " starring, Gurmit Singh [puke], Richard Ng, Tay Ping Hui and this geeky guy. The one and only reason why I wanted to do a review about that show was to bitch about Gurmit Singh. Synopsis A little introduction about the Brothers 4. It's Mediacorp's new dramedy about 4 brothers (hence the title. Woohoo, how innovative) with drastically different characters who try to survive each other and grapple with issues of family, love and life in Singapore (so says the official website). Mediacorp has been shamelessly plugging it's new dramedy for the past few weeks and the pilot episode was aired yesterday night after the "live" telecast of the NDP. Very strategic move, to ensure high viewership for the show. Characters So you have Richard Ng (he had a silent role in Tomb Raider pt 2) as the eldest brother Chung Fu. Strait-laced, stoic and self-righteous. Then you have Chung Guai played by Gurmit Singh [puke] a SNAG, and proud to be in touch with his inner (effiminate) self. Next, there is Chung Wing (Tay Ping Hui), a guy too good-looking for his own good. The baby of the family is Chung Hwa, a weirdo geek, who would probably be a child molester when he is older (in my opinion). Gripes Let it be known that I could not, COULD NOT sit through the entire episode. In fact, I turned the tv off after 15 mins (the episode was an hour long). The show was too wordy for its own good and delivery of the dialogue was flat. Despite Hong Kong bigwigs appearing in the show, like Richard Ng and Choo MiMi, there was nothing fantastic about the first 15 mins. I could not decide if the show was supposed to be a comedy or a drama. Sadly, although billed as a "dramedy", there was nothing comedic or dramatic, unless you include over-acting as dramatic, about the show. Most of the cast suited their respective roles EXCEPT Gurmit. It's ironic how he said in an interview that " I dont have any problems like some actors who cant get out of their role. " because traces of Phua Chu Kang was evident. He can't decide if his character should speak in a girly way or with a Singlish accent because he uses the 2 accents/speech styles interchangeably and it is very disconcerting hearing a man sounding like a gay and then like PCK. Not only that, in his eagerness to portray the SNAG, Gurmit also has a tendency to over-act, no surprises there. He looks ridiculous pretending to be effiminate, complete with the "limp-wrist" syndrome. Rather than becoming Chung Guai, it is also obvious that Gurmit is forcing himself to be the character and every limp-wrist movement is a conscious effort. Plus, those awful shirts do not look good on him. He is like an ageing clown who isn't funny anymore but still keeps trying. Someone should really tell him this, rather than give him the false impression tha he is still as funny as he was in the past.
HAPPY NATIONAL DAY!! urlLink Official NDP website

Movie Review - Secretary Secretary is a bizarre love story tinged with S&M and dark humour starring Maggie Gyllenhaal as Lee and James Spader as Edward Grey. Lee is a emotionally disturbed, shy young woman in her early 20s who was recently released from an instituition because she had been mutilating herself. Upon her release, she looked for work and became the secretary for an equally troubled lawyer (Edward Grey). As the show progresses, so does the relationship between Mr Grey and Lee. One of the highlights was when Mr Grey, a stickler for spelling, spanks Lee as she reads out the letter that she typed wrongly. Rather than disgust, Lee actually enjoys it and intentionally makes typo errors in order to be spanked. While working for Mr Grey, Lee blossoms from a shy, awkward girl to a self-confident, sexy woman. He, in turns, find a soulmate who exposes his emotional isolation and shy demeanor. The more we learn about Grey, who at first reveals nothing personal about himself, the more we oddly get to like him despite his eccentricities. The movie juxtaposes two types of relationships: the unconventional one Lee has with her boss and the "normal" relationship that she has with her long time friend, Peter. While the normal relationship would work for most people, it clearly was not working for Lee and in the end, she rejected marriage from Peter and went with Mr Grey instead. Opinions I really enjoyed the show. While the relationship between Lee and Mr Grey might be unnerving to some people, there is a certain vulnerability in both Lee and Mr Grey that tugs at my heartstrings. The tension and chemistry between the two stars is palpable. Spader and Gyllenhaal are excellent, but Gyllenhaal definitely stole the show. There is very little reliance on dialogue to move this story along. I especially liked the last 15 minutes of the movie and when Edward Grey bathed Lee. Although the movie was rated R, only towards the end do we see a nude body. Ratings I would definitely pay $8.50 for it. Heck, I'd watch it twice.

Where are my bones? Oof. I'm exhausted. Just got back from my first kickboxing class. Yes! It means that Nefi has actually paid for her AMORE fitness classes. [Round of applause people] I cannot imagine how such simple steps like "step kick step kick" can be so exhausting. Even jabs, hooks and uppercuts (ooh, boxing terminology) when done quickly are bloody tiring. I am now boneless and extremely sweaty. Heh, not a turn on, unless you're one of those people who like the au natural scent. I'm going to take a nice long shower. Hee, if only someone can bathe me a la the movie " Secretary ". Gonna do a review on it later.

Aliens from NZ... caine n tania ar really nice ppl, n i feel kindof bad dat nobody else besides me, got e chance to meet them... Question of e day: "hey, wats dat weird thing over there spitting water??" n they all agreed when i said dat e esplanade looks like a pair of fly's eyes... Things i learnt from e kiwis: - "called" n "cold" both sound like "cold"... apparently, e kiwis dun differentiate b/w e 2 sounds n only use e vowel sound for "o" in "cold" ie in linguistic terms, e 2 sounds ar allophones of e same phoneme in kiwi-english - "aye" can mean anything from "yes", or "uh-huh" to "huh??" - we ar exposed to western culture cos of tv n stuff, but they noe nuts abt us since tcs drama serials arent aired in NZ - they actually prefer our hectic lifestyle n communal unity (e grass is always greener on e other side) Things e kiwis learnt from me: - rojak is too spicy for them - ppl here ar always smiling, more so than back in kiwiland (which muz be agreed tho dat there ar more sheep than ppl there, n so theres something wrong wif our sample population) - everything is expensive in s'pore, except computers n movies - soya bean milk is called "dou jiang" n fried doughsticks "you tiao"

"Relieved of e imminence of physical death, sure of their daily bread, people turn to e death of love n friendship and endowed them wif e weight of mortality, and equated the omens of such failures wif a portentousness which in e Sudan applied to failures of rains, crops, and e deaths of children." kindof sad dat all e "life-changing" issues we worry or ar concerned abt, can be really trivial depending on e circumstances... which shld set us tinking abt wats really impt in life

Si j'avais ta tête a la place du cul j'aurais honte de chier - If my ass looked anything like your face, I'd be ashamed of taking a shit. Si les cerveaux étaient de l'essence, ils ne seraient pas suffisants pour faire tourner un kart de fourmis à l'intérieur d'un beignet - If brains were gasoline, he wouldn't have enough to run a piss ant's go-kart around the inside of a donut. Thanks for the word of encouragement from various friends. As I've said in my tagboard, there is another part to the story, which I didn't mention in the post because I was actually too tired to formulate my thoughts. I acknowledge that friends do grow up to be different, but sometimes, they retain enough common traits to continue the friendship. Yesterday's dessert thing was uncomfortable for me was not mainly due to the canoodling. Canoodling is annoying, but one gives a certain amount of leeway to couples (and their need to be touchy-feely). It was however, highly uncomfortable for me when we were walking because there were 2 couples lost in their own world in front, and me, straggling behind. What was sad was that, my friends kept talking about things that only the 4 of them knew about (being in the same society and faculty) but I was clueless to it all. That is where the tactless behaviour comes in. It's like speaking in your native language with your friends despite knowing that one of them does not speak that language. Of course, I would not expect the conversation to revolve around me. But there wasn't any common ground among us aside from our memories of school. However, that topic alone was insufficient. It never used to be so bad. Perhaps, it was because another friend (whom we also hung out with in school) used to come along whenever we met up, but he was unavailable last night. Funnily, my friendship with him has grown over the past few years although chances to meet have been few and far between. There were other factors as well that screwed up the night for me. But whatever it is, the event is over. I would not rule out meeting up in future, but unlike in the past where the decision was instanteneous, I would now think twice about it.

Has-Beens Nephthys baby, it goes for all. The reason why we set out so eagerly on such dates is because of memories . In our minds, we remember the good times and how it was fun . Because our last memory was a happy one, we set off for the current outing with anticipation and eagerness. Only to be disappointed. Let down. Deluded. Disillusioned. I am learning about expectations the hard way. It's so hard not to have any. Especially those pertaining to relationships with people - friendships, new friends, potential lovers, potential confidantes. So easy to just expect things to come out the way we dream about or want to. But how am I learning? I'm learning it's best not to expect anything. Like just go about these meetings and dates on a clean slate. Imagine being an innocent dummy about it. Simple. Unsuspecting. Held enthralled in wondrous amazement. Be prepared to be surprised how things will evolve or conclude. Don't go prepared expecting to have a good time. Especially pertains to engagements and appointments where no external entertainment (e.g. play/movie) is involved; where the only entertainment is the people itself. I realise that as we move along, with time, with our change in character, our view of life, our environment etc etc, we no longer see things the way we did before. Take for example your primary school assignments. Ever saw your handwriting and compositions back then? Doesn't it amaze you how you thought then? You'd probably go "man, i did not write this. No way. I actually thought like this??? Sweet heavens" (*shoves the paper back in the cupboard and make another uncommittal promise never to re-touch the cupboard) But we never thought we were thinkin' wrong then, did we. So there we have it about expectations. We change and the things we once held in truth may no longer hold the same degree of merit now. Friendships, I agree, are the especially painful ones. The type of knife that cuts deeper and leaves you bleeding internally. Because it just plain sucks that we know that once long ago, this was good, but now it's not. And being so, we are less likely to be willing to go out with the same group again. Nephthys love, don't bother yourself about being the Fifth wheel. I see it in a different way. Because they are your friends, just be in the mood with them. Act like a prissy chaperon or something. Or else when it gets to the point where everything you see makes your skin crawl and you can feel your inner organs starting to push out your back because you are holding your scream in, then just make up a cockamie excuse and leave. They will get the idea and although it seems like a dirty low-way to do it, such things are things 'that should not be named' and voiced out. Just appear like the cool babe you always are and hope in perhaps that they will be more conscious of their 'exhibitions' in the future esp. around single friends. Well, think of it this way, at least cheesecakes don't change so much. Haha.. c")

Friendships Meeting old friends is always a fun affair. You can catch up on old times, update each other about new happenings in your life and basically enjoy each others' company. The time when such reunions become awkward is when the friendship has run its course and you find that you have nothing much in common with your old friends. Sometimes, being different can strengthen a friendship, or even establish a new type of friendship. What is worst is when you realise that your friends have something in common among themselves and you are the one that has grown apart from them. The awkwardness becomes more palpable when the friends are dating one another, effectively making you the 5th wheel. Oh, the agony of having to endure couple whispers, while you are just staring at your cheesecake, wishing the night is over. But rarely do these friends mean to be tactless. They do, however, forget that sometimes an old friend (who is also a stranger) would actually feel left out amidst all that canoodling. It is sad when you know a friendship has run its course. It is a bittersweet feeling, remembering how it used to be and discovering what it is like now.

Music discovery hmm... okie... 9 bands n 54 songs later, i tink gothic rock doesnt really suit my taste, as weird as it may be... HIM is apparently e more radio-frenly band among e rest, n for those who ar interested, u may like to sample Passing Bird by Katatonia, City of Light by Theatre of Tragedy, n Wasting the Dawn by The 69 Eyes... e rest ar either too cultish or alternative for me... apparently, theres an irritating growling man in e backgrd for most gothic rock songs...

Movie Review - Magdalene Sisters Yes! finally got to catch this movie... wanted to during e film fest but it got sold out on e 2nd day of ticketing! also got my pair of complementary tix to Twilight Samurai, tho i wanted Dirty Pretty Things... but its ok, i shant complain too much since its free anyway... Synopsis: Its 1960s ireland, where e influence of catholicism remains strong thruout e republic... a govt-supported system is in place, which sends delinquent teenage gals to be reformed in convents... of cos, delinquency remains a relative term, which in e eyes of e irish catholic church means anything from flirtatious behaviour to looking too pretty for ur own gd... n so e brutality of e system is revealed thru e eyes of 3 gals... true stories of cos, portraying how they were deprived of all basic liberties, self-esteem, n e right to lead a life... Compliments: Peter Mullan weaves a depressing tale of senseless religious fervour, highlighting once more how human behaviour can at times appear so baffling n downright stupid when viewed from different perspectives... u have no choice but to sympathise wif e gals based upon their experiences alone... this is where e movie stands out, in its ability to evoke sympathy n sorrow, but is also a weakness as i shall explain later.... Gripes: its hard to see where Mullan attempts to present a balanced viewpt of e system... all e characters appear totally evil n vindictive, especially sister bridget... cld such a person have truly existed in reality? im sure e possibility is there, but i feel dat character devt for e nuns is severely lacking, while even e motivation for their staunch religious beliefs were neither explained nor significantly portrayed (tho there was a scene in which sister bridget teared as she watched a film)... Conclusion: well... it is a poignant movie criticising a system dat caused suffering amongst 10000s of children... perfect for those wanting to feel better abt themselves, by seeing how much sorrier lives others have led... 8.50 shld be worth it

BOO BOO IN THE NEWS The Malay-language paper, Berita Harian, made a HUGE boo-boo in yesterday's edition. In one of the photographs of a local soccer team in the locker room, a shot of a player's " other " member (if you know what I mean) was captured as well. Let me explain, this player was clad only in a towel and was standing with his legs apart. Little did he realise that his penis was poking out from the towel because he was too skimpily dressed. And this peek-a-boo pose was captured in the picture that appeared in the newspaper. Isn't it ironic how Singapore has always clamped down hard on nudity in the mass media, and unwittingly, one of the national newspapers featured a penis (at least the head of it) within its pages? Of course, it was an honest mistake, but heh, it was funny nonetheless. Will try to scan that pic in sometime.

10 Things I never knew until I started working: 1) having my own office is fucking great 2) the boss' hands are HUGE ! I reckon they can whip my head off if he were to slap me for some bizarre reason 3) work is just basically made up of itsy bitsy stuff that pile up at the end of the day 4) I would eventually have to clean the ladies toilet 5) No one else, apart from the receptionist and myself, seems to give a shit about punctuality 6) It is pretty nerve-wrecking working directly under the boss (but it's a small firm, so titles don't mean jack) 7) having my own office is fucking great! 8) The boss bites his pen, as seen from the chewed up ends 9) The boss sucks at spelling, hee, but the other one is a stickler for bad spelling 10) According to the boss, taking half off a day to settle bills at the bank is not considered a holiday, and thus, would not be taken off my annual leave.

The time has come. I'll be starting work tomorrow and I'm nervous, which is odd because I know the people in my firm, having worked for them before for about 2 months. Horror of horrors, I actually have to use (what's left of) my accounting knowledge. Oh dear. Time to drag out those books of mine. Fortunately or unfortunately (depending on how you want to look at it), I'll be one of only 2 ladies in the firm. Heh, yeah... imagine being surrounded by men all day. Ang moh men, because it is an expat firm. I've not met most of the people there and the only 2 men I know are the bosses. They are pretty nice and are very easy going, which is great. And they cuss alot, so heh, no need for me to curb my tongue. Mental note to self: Don't trip and show some sign of intelligence.

Movie Review - Camp I expected the show to be a slick production featuring talented kids belting out songs from musicals. But I was wrong. Directed by Todd Graff in 23 days on a shoe-string budget, Camp was all about summer camp for talented teens is as campy as its name. Starring mainly unknowns, the movie had an amateurish feel to it, from the bland acting to stilted directing, but it scored very highly on talent and exuberance. With the actors belting out songs from musicals throughout the movie, one can ignore the awkward acting. The Characters: In the opening sequences, we are introduced to the central characters of the movie. There is Vlad played by Daniel Letterle, the only straight boy whose good looks make him the object of affection for both boys and girls at camp. Next, we have his roommate mate, Michael, a pimply, gay Latino who wore a dress to his junior prom and was beaten up by jocks. The third character is Ellen (Joanna Chilcoat), a talented but insecure teenager who paid her brother to be her date for prom. There is also the camp vamp, Jill (Alana Allen) who has her own "helper" in fellow camp mate, Fritzi (Anna Kendrick). Along the way, one will also meet Dee (Sasha Allen) who likes Michael despite his homosexuality and Jenna (Tiffany Taylor) whose jaws were wired shut by her parents in their bid to get her to lose weight. The Plot: Essentially, Camp was about a performance camp, called Camp Ovation, where talented teens, shunned in their normal lives for being different, had to put up a new production every 2 weeks. In between rehearsals, the teens discovered themselves and fed their passion for performing. Vlad was the central character who was the object of Ellen's, Jill's and Michael's crush. Other subplots were also woven into the movie including Fritzi's revenge on Jill, the bitter camp director and his relationships with his young charges and other smaller plots. The comments: The strength of the movie definitely lies in the talented cast. Their renditions of broadway hits are fantastic. Anna Kendrick was especially great in her cynical, bitter rendition of "Ladies who lunch" and Tiffany Taylor stole the show when she bellted out the finale song. The dialogue, while cliched at times, showed surprising humour. When Jill was bitching about Ellen, a fellow teen said "I think I know your sister, Cinderella". Certain scenes also drew laughter from the audience, like the feedback from black camper and his young brother, Petey, to the camp master that they could not relate to being cast as Jews for Fiddler on the Roof . In response, the camp master cast 3 foot Petey as the dream man for the musical Dreamgirls . On the whole, the movie was fun and campy. It was also entertaining and the jokes were absolutely hilarious. The performances made up for the awkward acting. I would pay between $6.50 to $7.50 for it. Plus, Daniel Letterle is just CUTE!

Movie Review - Swimming Pool my 1st arthouse film since secretary... erm... tho secretary is debatable as being arthouse or juz plain weird... heheh... Synopsis: Sarah Morton is a prolific writer of detective stories (ala agatha christie)... Lacking in inspiration, she decides to have a holiday at her publisher's villa in e luberon, southern france, where she meets her publisher's nymphomanical daughter julie... 1 a typical prudish middle-aged brit wif morals as stiff as her upper lip, e other a sex-crazed youngster, a queer r/s soon develops, wif unexpected consequences.... Gripes: hmm... e soundtrack cld have been better, tho e lack of musical accompaniments seem to be e hallmark of low-budget arthouse films (except huit femmes n amelie)... not much is shown of e supposedly brilliant luberon countryside, which makes one doubt if its really filmed there at all... Compliments: this is only e 2nd francois ozon film i've seen (e other was huit femmes), n i muz admit his scripts ar highly original, n being a devotee of creative storylines wif totally unexpected twists, i really enjoyed e plot... his pick of his leads ar appropriate as well... sagnier appears convincing wif her role as julie, n well, lets juz say she has a nice figure... =p rampling was persuasive too, as a strait-jacketed woman wif represssed inclinations... however, i wasnt particularly impressed by e performances, since there isnt much room for more dramatic sequences anyway. Nevertheless, its e plot which captivates, enthralls, intrigues n finally surprises... shant tell u much more, else u wun enjoy it All in all: great movie to watch at 6.50, not bad if u pay 8.50, n well worth e money...

Maybe the pressure of having to make the marriage last longer than 12 months was too much for Ben to bear. urlLink Or maybe it was due to his excessive gambling and his mother . Aww hell, who gives a hoot anyways? I say put all of us out of our misery and either get married or break up for real. All this speculation is an unnecessary waste of space.

A case of the over-inflated ego urlLink What happens when one's ego becomes too big for one's voice ? Just ask Kelly Clarkson of American Idol fame. Ms Clarkson strolled into town last week to promote her Thankful album. Based on the report, she was snappy and threw a minor tantrum when told that the photo shoot would take place in the hotel lobby. Reason? Because there would be PEOPLE in the lobby. 'It's just that I hate people looking at me while I pose,' she explains, while faking a pose and a stiff smile. Yes, I'm sure that thousands of excited people would be dying to watch you pose. Puh-leeze, get your head out of the clouds and start living in the real world. So much for the girl-next-door appeal that won her millions of fans.

A night filled with 4 stand-up comedians from Ireland (Ed Byrne), Canada (Russell Peters), USA (Frank Olivier) and Australia (Carl Barron). Truth be told, the biggest draw for me was Ed Byrne. Having caught his Singapore act a few years ago, I have sorely missed his brand of humour ever since. This guy is absolutely hilarious; vulgar and rude, but funny nonetheless. So anyway, the other comedy show I watched was by the 1nitestand Comedy Club. Of course, travelling plans that I've made for the of the year will now be pushed to unspecified time and date. I'm quite excited to begin working (I am aware that I will most definitely complain about work soon) even though I've not been actively looking for a job. Amore fitness was a little boring after a while because I could not use the gym nor try any of the yoga classes. So, only time will tell if I do shed those pounds by the end of the year.

THE BACHELOR VS SURVIVOR: PEARL ISLANDS This week marks the beginning of two new seasons of The Bachelor and Survivor (the mother of ALL reality tv shows). It is funny how great reality tv thrives on conflicts between the participants. Frankly, it makes the show more interesting. Who wants to watch 4 people getting along very well when one can watch 4 different people bitching about one another? If one had to pick a favourite reality tv show from either The Bachelor or Survivor, death is not an option here people, which one would it be? To watch 25 women fight over some guy or 16 castaways plotting their teammates death? This latest instalment of The Bachelor would probably be even more vicious because the bachelor, a certain Mr Andrew Firestone is actually a MILLIONNAIRE. Yes, unlike, Evan "the beast" Mariott from Joe Millionnaire. From the trailers that Mediacorp has been shoving down our throats lately, the women are no doubt beautiful, because anyone who spends at least 1 hour putting on her makeup will definitely look beautiful, and very, very catty. Of course, Andrew Firestone would be lapping it all up as it is a TREMENDOUS boost to his ego to know that 25 women are fighting over him. Ooh, so who will he choose? Let me end your misery by saying that he will choose Jen (the benefits of being about 1 season behind the US is that one can read about the show if one wishes to). Andrew Firestone is the prize for the winner. On the contrary, Survivor is as dirty as the Bachelor is glamourous. While the Bachelor is out to fulfill the women's fantasies, Survivor will bring hell to those who can't, well, survive. In Pearl Islands, our castaways will be marooned in Panama. Get ready for more back-stabbing as all 16 castaways will be fighting for the $1 million. So back to the question at hand, of the two, which one would be a favourite? I would pick Survivor. First, I never liked watching 25 women living in a house together. That is definitely a recipe for disaster. As unfeminist as this sounds, women should not live together because they would bitch and bitch and bitch. Secondly, bah, who wants to watch said women living out their fantasies? Thirdly, who wants to watch one man sucking face with said women? Fourthly, winning $1 million is way cooler than getting picked to be Mrs Firestone (yes, I'm fully aware that Andrew Firestone would be worth more than $1 million). Lastly, at least Survivor has games. In The Bachelor, the only games they would be playing would probably involve a naked woman and naked man, both of which I wouldn't want to see.

--__-- have u ever felt as if theres nothing to look forward to in life? everything seems to be black n white... bland... nothing excites u... n then u start wundering abt wat it is exactly u want in life, wat motivates u, wat makes u passionate... b4 u realise dat u cant tink of anything which wld make u feel upbeat n vibrant again... how to begin a search when i dun even noe wat im searching for?

Philosophers n linguists shld learn how to write in simple english!!! okie... im sick of those protracted, verbose, bombastic diatribes, filled wif convoluted sentences e length of entire paragraphs, and written in e name of erudition n academia... one doesnt pay to be a student n have to read crap from ppl who cant string decent arguments together for nuts, n yet claim to be founding fathers of e epistemological world... erm... in other words, e convention of academic writing appears to be sophistication, and it doesnt matter wat u write, so long as u sound chim... which shldnt be e case at all, since e whole pt abt writing expository essays, is to communicate ur ideas as efficiently and clearly as possible. let me show u some typical sentences i have to read, wk in wk out... Foucalt (king of pretty phrases dat dun make sense): " That should not, i believe, be taken to mean that its qualities are those of an obtuse, naive or primitive empiricism; nor is it a soggy eclecticism, an opportunistim that laps up any and every kind of theoretical approach; nor does it mean a self-imposed ascetism which taken by itself would reduce to the worst kind of theoretical impoverishment ." - wat on earth is soggy eclecticism or primitive empiricism??? Bordieu (another frenchie who luvs loooong sentences): " On the one hand, there are the socially constructed dispositions of the linguistic habitus, which imply a certain propensity to speak and to say determinate things (the expressive interest) and a certain capacity to speak, which involves both the linguistic capacity to generate an infinite number of grammatically correct discourses, and the social capacity to use this competence adequately in a determinate situation ." - by e time i get thru e last part of it, i forgot wat e 1st part is abt... Chomsky (master of e circular argument): " A code is not a set of representations but rather a specific system of rules that assigns coded representations to message-representations ." - x = y therefore y = x... wat stoopid formula is this??

Convocation Now that I am more lucid, it will be easier for me to describe my convocation in greater detail rather than yesterday's brief post. Woke up with a start because had a dream about waking up late and having to dress in school. Thankfully, it was a rainy day so our make up did not melt as much or as fast as usual. Even so, wearing that many layers of clothes in this humid climate was godawful! Toes felt squashed and they became numb eventually. The atmosphere was mildly chaotic and it was difficult locating familiar faces. The ceremony started at 3. By this time, guests and graduates were already seated, enjoying the comforts of the plush chair and the air-conditioning. I was falling asleep in my seat. The ceremony was anti-climatic. We had already received our transcripts on the day we collected our gowns and there were no performances. The only music played was for the professors who strolled in. Actually, with all the professors dressed in their robes, the auditorium looked like a scene from Harry Potter. Hee, that was funny. Having a name starting with the letter A has its perks. I was the 5th one in my group to go on stage. My friend and I were surprisingly nervous. Thankfully, we just had to walk on stage, shake the guy's hands, receive an empty folder and walk down. As I waited for my turn, I wondered what it would be like to be naked under the gown and flash the man as I received my folder. Hmm.. Bad idea. I doubt he would appreciate it. Furthermore, being arrested on my convocation day is so not cool. It would have been fun if everyone wasn't so serious about it. The last girl had the loudest cheers. Hee. Refreshments were provided. Finger foods abound for hungry graduates and their families. We stuffed our faces with dim sum, an assortment of cakes/kuih, and noodles. My friends and I split up and I took pictures with my parents around school, especially at the Yunnan Garden. That was fun. Another round of photo taking will take place next week. This time, the venue will at the Esplanade and Boat Quay. Watch out for more pics.
